block.p: Your April 15 editorial ''On Rethinking the Javits Center'' hit just the right notes. But the concerns you raised -- constructing a secure and workable center, engaging the waterfront and promoting the development of the West Side -- cannot be achieved unless the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's western railyard is included in convention center expansion plans.

Your April 15 editorial ''On Rethinking the Javits Center'' hit just the right notes. But the concerns you raised -- constructing a secure and workable center, engaging the waterfront and promoting the development of the West Side -- cannot be achieved unless the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's western railyard is included in convention center expansion plans.

Without the M.T.A. railyard, there is simply not enough land for a workable center with sufficient exhibition space; 39th and 40th Streets' connections to the waterfront will be cut off; and $2 billion invested in an expanded convention center north of 34th Street will make it that much harder to ''level the old monster,'' as you recommend.

If the expansion is built on the M.T.A. railyard, however, more prime exhibition space could be provided, 39th and 40th Streets could remain open and eventually the ''old monster'' could be relocated elsewhere to make room for residential development and an appealing waterfront park.
Daniel Gutman Meta Brunzema Hell's Kitchen
The writers are, respectively, an urban planner and an architect.
